This project has three main scientific thrusts:
(a) The first and broadest thrust concerns elastic-energy-driven pattern formation in thin elastic sheets. The investigator studies stress-driven patterns involving wrinkles, folds, delamination, and other defects, with particular emphasis on situations where the energy-minimizing pattern develops fine-scale structure as the sheet thickness tends to zero. His approach is to focus on how the minimum energy scales with respect to the sheet thickness and other relevant physical parameters.
(b) The second thrust concerns surface-energy-driven coarsening of two-phase mixtures. The investigator studies a family of nonlocal evolutions from the physics literature, which generalize the relatively well-understood model of "Cahn-Hilliard dynamics." The focus here is on understanding the large-time coarsening rate.
(c) The third thrust concerns prediction with expert advice (a topic from the machine learning literature). The investigator's goal is a fresh perspective on some regret-minimization-based algorithms for prediction. He views regret minimization as a robust control problem and considers a suitable scaling limit in which the associated value function solves a differential equation.

The investigator studies three interdisciplinary topics. The first two lie at the interface where mathematics meets physics and materials science, while the third lies at the interface with machine learning. In each area, challenges from applications drive the development of new mathematical methods. For example, the work on thin elastic sheets is helping develop a theory of energy-minimizing patterns, in much the same way that consideration of soap bubbles and soap films led to the theory of minimal surfaces a generation ago. It is of course a familiar fact that thin sheets often wrinkle or fold: our skin wrinkles and our clothes wrinkle; leaves, flowers, and hanging drapes have folds. Physical experiments in controlled settings can quantify such phenomena, and numerical simulations can demonstrate within a model how the patterns develop. But neither experiment nor simulation can tell us "why" a system chooses a particular pattern. The project provides a valuable complement to other methods, by showing that elastic energy minimization requires types of patterns. The project provides training opportunities for graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addressed a broad range of challenges from materials science and machine learning using methods from the calculus of variations, optimal control, and nonlinear partial differential equations. In many cases these challenges drove the development of new mathematical techniques. 


The formation of wrinkling or folding patterns in thin elastic sheets was a major focus. This phenomenon is familiar: our skin wrinkles and our clothes wrinkle; leaves, flowers, and hanging drapes have folds. There is in fact a growing body of scientific work in this area, driven by the recognition that wrinkling patterns are different from -- but share features with -- patterns seen in other physical systems such as liquid crystals, ferromagnets, and shape-memory materials. These systems share the feature that their stable configurations are local minima of a nonconvex variational problem with a regularizing higher-order term. The analysis of "energy-driven pattern formation" in such systems is a current frontier in the calculus of variations. Until recently, theoretical work relied mainly on minimizing the energy within a particular ansatz. This method can only give an upper bound on the minimum energy. The PI and his collaborators have introduced methods for proving ansatz-free lower bounds on the minimum energy. When the lower bounds and upper bounds are close to agreement, they tell us which patterns are preferred by energy minimization, and why. Over the course of this project a variety of wrinkling problems were analyzed from this viewpoint, including the coarsening of folds in hanging drapes, the wrinkles seen in a ribbon that is twisted and slightly stretched, and the geometry-driven wrinkling seen when a flat sheet is wrapped around a sphere. 


The mechanics of thin structures with misfit was another focus. The fact that misfit (due for example to thermal strain) can induce deformation in a thin structure is well-known; a familiar example is the use of bimetallic strips in the design of thermostats. While simple cases like bilayers are well-understood, the general case (involving an arbitrary misfit) requires different methods. An improved understanding could be useful for designing sheets that deform in predictable ways upon heating. Studies done as part of this project included one concerning the bending and twisting of a rod with misfit, and one concerning the effective bending energy of a sheet with misfit. 


A rather different focus involved prediction with expert advice. This machine learning subdiscipline considers an agent who must make a sequence of choices ("predictions") based on the guidance of some "experts". Probabilistic modeling of the past or the future is not involved; rather, the agent's goal is to "minimize regret" -- that is, to minimize his worst-case shortfall with respect to the (retrospectively) best-performing expert. The PI and his students have focused on model problems that can be viewed as zero-sum, sequential, two-person games. In the literature, these problems have mainly been analyzed using discrete methods. The PI and his students have developed a fresh perspective and obtained new results by using methods from optimal control and partial differential equations.


Other  topics considered as part of this project included the effect of random or periodic pinning sites upon driven mean-curvature flow; the axial compression of a thin cylindrical shell stabilized by a rigid mandrel core; a variational problem from the theory of mean field spin glasses; stochastic homogenization of variational problems; and some questions from optimal transport. 


Much of the project's budget was devoted to support for PhD students, and over a dozen students were associated with the project over its 6-year timeframe. They gained valuable multidisciplinary experience while contributing strongly to the project's success.
